entries.content: Focus the initial part of a call on gathering information rather than selling.
"How are you doing this morning?"
Ask for permission to continue the conversation early in the call.
"Would you like to hang up or let me have 30 seconds?"
Use an inquisitive opening to immediately establish a buyer-seller dynamic where you are asking questions.
"How are you guys currently dealing with X problem?"
Reference a trigger event or recent news about the prospect's company to show you've done research.
"I saw that you guys just raised another round of funding..."
Use mutual connections or relevant past experiences as a way to build credibility and rapport quickly.
"I noticed you previously worked at [Company Name]..."
State the core value proposition or intent of the call very concisely and early.
"The reason for my call is we help companies like yours do X..."
Frame the call around potential benefits for the prospect, such as saving time or money.
"Would you be opposed to a quick chat about how we might be able to save you X?"
Use pattern interrupt techniques to break through a prospect's assumptions about a cold call.
"I know this is a cold call..."
entries.notes: Acknowledging the nature of the call as a pattern interrupt.

entries.content: Focus on delivering value or insight immediately, rather than just pitching.
Structure the call opening to transition quickly from pleasantries to the reason for the call and a permission request.
Be prepared with a concise value statement (elevator pitch) that is relevant to the specific prospect.
Deliver your opening quickly to respect the prospect's time.
Maintain a confident and clear tone throughout the opening.
Use 'we' language when talking about your company's capabilities or value proposition.
